statement.text: Elective AAA repair is indicated for aneurysm diameter ≥5.5 cm in men and ≥5.0 cm in women, rapid expansion ≥0.5 cm in 6 months, or symptoms attributable to the aneurysm. The decision balances rupture risk against operative risk. Repair is recommended when rupture risk exceeds operative mortality - typically 2-3%/year rupture risk threshold compared to 2-4% perioperative mortality for elective EVAR/open repair.
statement.formal: Repair Indications: Diameter ≥5.5 cm (men) | ≥5.0 cm (women) | Growth ≥0.5 cm/6 months | Symptomatic aneurysm | Saccular morphology | Decision: Rupture risk > Operative risk

explanation.intuition: The decision to repair an AAA is like deciding when to fix a slowly bulging tire. A small bulge can be monitored safely. But at some point, the risk of a blowout (rupture) becomes high enough that it outweighs the risks of repair. That tipping point is around 5.5 cm for men. Below 5 cm, rupture risk is very low (~1%/year), but above 5.5 cm it climbs rapidly (~10%/year at 6 cm, 25%+ at 7 cm).
explanation.key_insight: There's no magic diameter at which rupture occurs - 5.5 cm is the threshold where rupture risk begins to exceed operative risk for most patients. Individual factors matter: women have higher rupture risk at smaller sizes (hence the 5.0 cm threshold), patients with high operative risk may benefit from a higher threshold, and saccular/rapidly expanding aneurysms warrant earlier repair.
explanation.technical_details: Rupture risk by size: <4 cm = 0%/year; 4.0-4.9 cm = 0.5-1%/year; 5.0-5.9 cm = 3-15%/year; 6.0-6.9 cm = 10-20%/year; ≥7 cm = 20-32%/year. Key trials: UK Small Aneurysm Trial and ADAM trial showed no survival benefit to early repair of 4.0-5.5 cm AAA vs surveillance. Women have 3-4x higher rupture risk at same diameter - hence lower threshold. Operative mortality: EVAR 1-2%, open 3-5% at high-volume centers. Patient factors affecting threshold: life expectancy (<2-5 years may not benefit), fitness for surgery, anatomy (suitable for EVAR?), patient preference.
common_misconceptions: Every AAA eventually needs repair - many patients die of other causes first
5.5 cm is a hard cutoff - it's a guideline balancing risks, not a mandate
Women use the same size threshold - women have higher rupture risk, lower threshold
Small aneurysms never rupture - rare but possible, especially if symptomatic

definitions_glossary.elective_repair: Planned surgical repair of intact aneurysm before rupture
definitions_glossary.rupture_risk: Probability of aneurysm rupturing per year
definitions_glossary.operative_mortality: Risk of death within 30 days of surgery
definitions_glossary.size_threshold: Diameter at which repair benefits outweigh risks
definitions_glossary.expansion_rate: Change in diameter over time, typically cm/year

standard_indications: Expansion rate ≥0.5 cm over 6 months or ≥1.0 cm/year
factors_for_delayed_repair: Unfavorable anatomy (poor EVAR candidate, no open option)

definition.@value: Evidence-based criteria for recommending elective AAA repair based on rupture and operative risk

sources.citation: Chaikof EL, et al. SVS practice guidelines for AAA. J Vasc Surg. 2018;67(1):2-77.
ADAM Trial. N Engl J Med. 2002;346:1437-1444.

learning_objectives: State the standard size thresholds for AAA repair
Explain the relationship between rupture risk and diameter
Identify factors that modify the repair threshold
Apply shared decision-making for borderline cases
clinical_pearls: Women: lower threshold (5.0 cm) because of higher rupture risk
Rapid growth matters more than absolute size
Small aneurysm trials: no benefit to repairing <5.5 cm
Individual decision based on rupture risk vs operative risk
